ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how to think critically about Russia and US today and the past. I thought from a more real politic lens than I had before and thought about it as a geopolitical issue that has to be dealt with pragmatically.
Critical engagement into specifics of US-Russia relations, ability to work with documents and original political statements, analyzing strategies and white books
Writing and speaking concisely about policy

Through the course, the historical American and Russian relations were studied, the dimensions of the formation of this relationship and its future, as well as the interests associated with the two countries and their competition for great powers.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I loved the format. I sometimes wish Professor Graham would lead more.

Strengths: Professional experience of Mr Graham makes the course unique in terms of ability to gain the first hand experience of the strategic dialogue and other areas of US-Russia engagement after the end of the Cold War
Weaknesses: Absence of Russian language skills of the most of the class makes prevents a deeper engagement in the subject matter

Good overview of the topic; interesting methodology based on instructor's policy experience (tables etc.). There was significant divergence between students in the extent of prior knowledge, experience and understanding of the topic, but that is probably unavoidable.
The strength of the course is Mr. T. Graham, with his vast experience in this field, he presents the topics in an interesting way with rich information and analysis.

The most valuable topics covered were the policy making mechanisms and guiding documents of the Russian Federation. Analyzing varying issue-based policies from the stand point of both the U.S. and Russian side was also useful.

The policy modeling workshops were an interesting exercise, and more of them should be incorporated into the class on various topics. 

Some of the course material is a bit outdated. It would also be valuable to trace the arc of Russian political decline towards autocracy to understand its impact on the bilateral relations.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes. But, only if you are willing to be in an intense environment. The students can be a bit aggressive. Also, I felt like I was trying effortlessly on my essays and no matter what I couldn't make it better.
Yes, I will recommend this course, particularly for those, who are ready to engage in a critical reflection over US-Russia relations of the past 30 years
Yes, I would recommend to anyone who wants to have a policy-oriented course.
Yes, this course is focused on a perpetually relevant topic and the instructor has a wealth of knowledge and experience in the field.
